data.title: Add semicolons to README.MD
SASS for styles
data.body: Is it possible to use another CSS preprocessor for the styles config file for Atom (e.g SASS, SCSS)?

data.title: ^M artifacts upon editing with ATOM PHP files.
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Here is what's happening. In my home directory, the WP config files are full of ^M artifacts. This is preventing the system understand the file, hence why it can't read what the php values are on the server.

This result upon editing all my config files with Atom. Anything you would suggest to never repeat this again?
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Used Transmit and Atom as editors
2. Open any wp-config.php file edit it save it and then issues are there.
3. [and so on...]

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
Just a working php file.
**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
Files contains ^M artifacts.
### Versions

1.5.4
You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line.

data.title: Conflicted file is not marked as modified
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [ ] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Files that have conflicts in them after a failed merge are not detected as modified in the Tree View or Status Bar, but Git Diff shows the changes correctly.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Find a branch that has conflicts with another branch
2. Attempt to merge the two
3. Open a file that has conflicts
4. Observe that the Tree View does not color the file as modified, and the Status Bar also reports no changes

**Expected behavior:** Tree View and Status Bar to detect changes

**Actual behavior:** No changes are detected other than Git Diff
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line.

```
Atom    : 1.7.0-dev-8472f91
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```

/cc @joshaber here's another one for you!

data.title: Atom should warn on non-dev-mode launch when a default-installed package is overridden in ~/.atom/packages
data.body: ### Prerequisites - [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)? (duplicated packages aren't loaded in Safe Mode) - [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)? - [X] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)? - [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)? - [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)? - [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported? For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide. ### Description Having an additional copy of a default-installed package in `~/.atom/packages` can cause hard-to-diagnose bugs: - https://github.com/atom/git-diff/issues/85 - among others Sometimes having an overridden version of a default-installed package is useful for Atom developers but it seems to be causing problems and frustration for unsuspecting regular users. The proposal here is to show an error notification on launch if Atom is not in Dev or Safe Mode. Something like: ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Install a duplicate Core package (ignore the warning) using `apm install git-diff` 2. Launch Atom **Expected behavior:** A warning to appear **Actual behavior:** No warning is shown ### Versions You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. ``` Atom : 1.7.0-dev-f88051e Electron: 0.36.8 Chrome : 47.0.2526.110 Node : 5.1.1 ```

data.title: atom launches with no workspace or menus after build/install
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [N] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [Y] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [N] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [Y] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [Y] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [Y] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

After install a new version following guide available at https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/docs/build-instructions/linux.md when trying to launch atom interface window doesn't show any workspace or menus, just a blank browser screen, even removing .atom on home directory doesn't solve (as an attempt to fix this behavior).
### Steps to Reproduce
- Follow steps to install a new version of atom referenced above

data.title: MSI installer
data.body: In order to deploy the installation / update of the software, it would be useful if the installer was in MSI format.

data.title: Better selection
data.body: Please add in the ability to double click in between quotes and that would select all the text within the quotes instead of the whole line if double click again then the whole line would be highlighted as it does now.

data.title: Add option editor.showCursorWhenSelecting - Cursor Visible While Selecting
data.body:
This is a very common feature for most IDEs, I've used the same identifier as CodeMirror's option in this case `showCursorWhenSelecting`.

This is a very small fix for something that cannot be addressed with a plugin AFAIK, thank you.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2925395/13560995/ad524bf2-e3ec-11e5-80b8-4ad86564c48a.png)

data.title: 1.6 releases
Don't assign scrollLeft on model on 'scroll-left-changed' events
data.body:
Fixes #2513

I'm not entirely sure why, but for some reason we're getting into an
feedback cycle when the scrollLeft position changes in certain cases. In
theory, this shouldn't happen because reassigning the same value
shouldn't emit a change event. But since we're about to end-of-life the
jQuery editor, I'd like to try fixing it this way for now.

data.title: Feature Request: Tree View Groups & Custom Project Names
data.body:
The Atom Tree View should allow users to group projects and show/hide those groups. Also it should allow users to set custom project names (instead of showing the actual folder names).

**Current and suggested behavior**

Currently you will have to remove projects from Tree View when you don't need them anymore and don't want to inundate the UI. Also you will have to name your projects folder unique to know what you're inside.

This should be not necessary anymore.  
It should be possible to group projects, like:

```
organization A
-- project 1
-- project 2
organization B
-- project 1
-- project 2
```

Also it should be possible to adjust the name that is shown in Tree View for a project.

**Why would the enhancement be useful to most users**

When you are working for multiple organizations or you are using Atom for private and for business purposes, you would want to separate projects.

When working on projects where the source code is just a part of it, you will often name the source code folder "sandbox" or "repository". In Atom Tree View you will lose the overview when having multiple folders called the same.

Both things are possible in Eclipse. Eclipse stores the name of a project in `.project`. Groups are saved in internal files. 
In my opinion those things should be stored in internal files, that they can not be copied to a remote repository by mistake.

**Atom Version:** 1.5.3
**OS and Version:** Windows 10

data.title: apm install failed in HTTP 404 error when gyp is downloading node.js with a fresh install atom
data.body:
### Description

[Description of the bug or feature]
apm install failed in HTTP 404 error when gyp is downloading node.js with a fresh install gyp. This issue will stop new users from downloading any package.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Mac Refresh install ATOM latest version: 1.54
2. goto command line
3. type: "apm install script"
4. 404 happen:

```
bogon:~ linwei$ apm install script
Installing script to C:\Users\linwei\.atom\packages
gyp info it worked if it ends with ok
gyp info using node-gyp@2.0.2
gyp info using node@0.10.40 | win32 | ia32
gyp http GET https://atom.io/download/atom-shell/v0.34.5/node-v0.34.5.tar.gz
gyp http 404 https://atom.io/download/atom-shell/v0.34.5/node-v0.34.5.tar.gz
gyp WARN install got an error, rolling back install
gyp
bogon:~ linwei$ 
```

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
package 'script' should be installed if I type "apm install script"

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
gyp failed into 404, seems like gyp doesn't recognize http 302 redirection.
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line.

```
bogon:~ linwei$ atom --version
1.5.4
bogon:~ linwei$ apm --version
apm  1.6.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.5.4
```

data.title: Reindexing message should not cause jumpy list.
data.body:
(Latest Atom beta):
This is some design feedback on the command+t panel (in the `One Dark` theme). The fact that the "reindexing project" message appears is pretty cool - however, because of how the layout is designed, it causes the list itself to jump (which makes it distracting). The layout should preserve a place for messages to be shown in the dialog without causing the list rows to jump around when the "reindexing" message is shown/hidden).

I'm not sure if this is related only to the `One Dark` theme, because I saw it happen with multiple UI themes. Fixing this would make Atom feel more solid.

data.title: Add TextEditors to the registry only when opting in
data.body:
This PR makes it so `TextEditors` are added to the registry only when they explicitly opt in.
This was mentioned in atom/atom#10851 (where I forgot to include it) to avoid leaking memory due to package authors not calling `destroy`.

/cc @nathansobo

data.title: Scroll to cursor on unfold all
data.body:
In **`text-editor.coffee`**, call `scrollToCursorPosition` on the `unfoldAll` handler.

![atom-unfold-all-fixed](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1685621/13551477/0c1789d2-e31a-11e5-9798-d37a6031d09e.gif)

---

Fixes #11066.

data.title: "The editor has crashed", no way to know what's really happening.
data.body:
I've build `atom` on archlinux, but everytime I run it, I eventually get `The editor has crashed`.

The fact that editor crashes is nothing special, in fact not an issue, but I am literally unable to provide any further information! This message is the only thing that appears. I **DO** know that this is unhelpful, and that's exactly the problem.

What I've done:
-> Tried checking `/tmp/Atom Crashes`, but it was... empty
-> Tried running with the `-f` option, only find out that it's impossible to get crash dump id:

```
$ atom -f
[1928:0305/185349:ERROR:browser_main_loop.cc(203)] Running without the SUID sandbox! See https://code.google.com/p/chromium/wiki/LinuxSUIDSandboxDevelopment for more information on developing with the sandbox on.
[1928:0305/185350:INFO:audio_manager_pulse.cc(257)] Failed to connect to the context.  Error: Connection refused
[1928:0305/185351:WARNING:accelerator_util.cc(118)] Invalid accelerator token: command
[1928:0305/185351:WARNING:accelerator_util.cc(118)] Invalid accelerator token: command
[1928:0305/185351:WARNING:accelerator_util.cc(118)] Invalid accelerator token: command
[1928:0305/185351:WARNING:accelerator_util.cc(118)] Invalid accelerator token: command
App load time: 2081ms
[1928:0305/185354:INFO:CONSOLE(52)] "Window load time: 1539ms", source: file:///usr/local/share/atom/resources/app.asar/static/index.js (52)
[1928:0305/185356:INFO:CONSOLE(0)] "/deep/ combinator is deprecated. See https://www.chromestatus.com/features/6750456638341120 for more details.", source:  (0)
Failed to get crash dump id.
Report Id: 
```

-> I've read the [debugging](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging) info, only to find out that I am not as lucky not to have this issue in `--safe` mode, and I can't check my settings since the editor crashes

->`~/.atom/nohup.out` shows nothing more (and this super secret file location wasn't included in the debugging document....)

I don't know any other secret tricks to get more info.

data.title: Maxed CPU when updating packages
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [N, but this is irrelevant, it's a bug in apm] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [Y] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [Y] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [Y] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [Y] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [Y] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Updating an atom package takes 100% or more CPU.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Be on Mac OS X El Capitan
2. Update a somewhat large package.
3. Close tab.

**Expected behavior:** It should have updated quietly.

**Actual behavior:** My fans turned on, my CPU was maxing out at 170% usage from apm.
### Versions

Latest version.

data.title: git bash cannot find atom
data.body:
I downloaded a latest version of atom, and rebooted my computer. Then, I ran git bash, wrote "atom .", and git bash said "bash: atom: command not found". What should I have to do?
p.s. I updated windows 7 to windows 10, and I cannot find like install shell commands menu.

data.title: Modify selection to stop highlight at new-line (instead of continuing to end-of-screen)
data.body:
Continued work by @vjeux from https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/8640

It's mostly the same as what @vjeux had but I further extend the selection to select the new line (as it does in sublime and vs code).

---

Some general direction on how to go from there and I don't mind going through the specs and adjusting.

Now.. I'm not sure how to get the rounded corners that VS Code and Sublime have on the selection. I tried playing with border-radius and it sort of works but we need these triangles to fill in the bottom-right border radius (but only if the line is shorter than the line under it). An idea I had is we could perhaps switch to constructing a single SVG Path that is filled for selection. Perhaps @simurai knows a creative method to make it work in CSS. If there is a reasonable method to do this with CSS; the rounded selection could be left up to a theme to implement (and leave corner with pointy corner selection).

---

A question before I delve too much deeper. Is this something that would be accepted if we figure out a good solution? @nathansobo @benogle

data.title: Wrong character being inserted when period key is pressed
data.body:
### Description

I'm facing an strange behavior, where, for no reason and happening at random moments, my period key begins to insert the '>' character instead the period one.

I couldn't figure out yet a pattern or even steps to reproduce it, since this bug happens randomly.

The only way I found to fix it is rebooting.

Facing this problem on Ubuntu Linux, Atom v.1.5.3 and French (Azerty) keyboard.
### Steps to Reproduce

Couldn't find a pattern or steps to reproduce yet.

**Expected behavior:** When the period key is pressed, a period mark should be inserted on text.

**Actual behavior:** When the period key is pressed, the symbol '>' is placed instead.
### Versions

Atom: **v1.5.3**
APM: **v1.0.1**
NPM: **v2.5.1**
Node: **v0.10.35**
Python: **v2.7.6**
Git: **v1.9.1**

data.title: Remove linter warnings in menus cson
data.body:
According to the [Atom's CoffeeScript Styleguide](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#coffeescript-styleguide):

> Avoid spaces inside the curly-braces of hash literals.

data.title: Atom build env and apm use `ATOM_ACCESS_TOKEN` env var for different things
data.body:
Both atom's build process and apm use the `ATOM_ACCESS_TOKEN` environment variable for different things. [Atom's build env](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/1d72fc8a455d6fec628a32f05639bb943b916f75/build/Gruntfile.coffee#L255) is looking for a GitHub token, while [apm](https://github.com/atom/apm/blob/9fb023196f1631d5ab2d6375991ee747db5e96d7/src/auth.coffee#L24) is looking for an atom.io token. So if I set it for building, I cant publish packages, and if I set it for publishing, I have trouble building (from scratch for electron donwload; at HQ cause unauth'd API access is saturated).
### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.7.0-dev-fa6905f
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```
